executive_summary: The computer stores industry has experienced moderate volatility in recent years. Significant competition from consumer electronic stores and upstream producers has put downward pressure on revenue growth. However, the growing reliance of consumers on computers for personal use, work, and school has led to significant revenue gains. This trend was enhanced in 2020 due to the pandemic, which pushed many workers and students to operate remotely, driving computer sales. Similarly, growing disposable income during this time and retailers passing down cost increases to consumers contributed to these gains.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Multiple Factors Have Led to the Growth of the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Although computer stores have been falling in popularity because of the growth in demand for major retailers, such as Best Buy, they are still a common outlet for consumers to buy computers. During the 2020 pandemic, the large need for computers, particularly as remote working and learning became the norm, contributed to jumping sales. The rising price of computers also supported revenue growth. Supply chain disruptions and higher semiconductor prices pushed stores to pass down cost increases to buyers, boosting revenue. Growing disposable income has also supported computer sales as consumers buy more electronics and other discretionary products when economic conditions are favorable.

Computer stores are subject to strong external competition from consumer electronics stores, upstream computer manufacturers, and software developers like Microsoft. Manufacturers and software developers, in particular, can offer lower prices to consumers, posing a significant threat. Retailers such as Best Buy and Walmart leverage their brands and contracts with manufacturers to sell computers and peripheral equipment at competitive prices, agreements that smaller stores are often unable to reach. Online shopping platforms allow consumers to compare products and make informed decisions without needing to speak with store associates, eliminating the need to visit a specialized computer retail establishment.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Computer Stores are Looking to Adapt
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While external competitors have largely met most demand, retailers have benefited from adding services like repairs and having highly trained employees to support consumers while shopping. Some stores have diversified their product offerings to include other consumer electronics products. Still, this has drawn revenue away from the industry because these retailers are often transitioning to operate in the consumer electronics stores space. Rising consumer spending and a household computer ownership boost have supported computer stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving Economic Conditions Drive Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The ongoing economic recovery is forecast to continue over the coming years. Rising disposable income, growing consumer confidence and falling inflation will support new computer sales and revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE NEED FOR NEW TECHNOLOGY WILL FUEL DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rapid rate of technological development encourages consumers to replace their computers on a semi-consistent basis. New technologies will continue to be developed over the coming years, driving revenue growth. Many businesses aim to stay on top of technological developments, a trend that has become more common as automation has enabled many companies to become more efficient. The need for these cost-saving measures will drive business users to invest in automation and computing technology.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SIGNIFICANT EXTERNAL COMPETITION FORCES RETAILERS TO ADAPT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To compete with large consumer electronics retailers such as Best Buy, many computer stores will continue expanding their product lines to include other electronics and value-added services. Since by selling directly to consumers, upstream producers can become more profitable and competitive, direct-to-consumer sales will continue growing over the coming years, threatening demand for computer stores. These heightened levels of external competition will prevent retailers from becoming significantly more profitable. However, the growing demand for new computers and other electronics will enable the industry to continue growing.

industry_definition: This industry includes computer stores that mainly retail desktops, notebook computers and software and accessories, like printers, scanners and keyboards. These goods are purchased from domestic and international.

opportunities: Percentage of households with at least one computer

key_trends: Computer stores contend with high internal competition. Retailers compete by continuously adjusting prices to appeal to consumers and raise their market share through increased sales.

External competition poses a significant threat. External competitors include consumer electronics stores, e-commerce retailers and software and computer manufacturers, which consumers often find to be more convenient.
Retailers with e-commerce capabilities grew during the pandemic. During this time, many consumers needed computers to work-from-home or take classes remotely, supporting revenue.

A consistent need for new technology supports revenue growth. Upstream manufacturers develop new technologies often, encouraging consumers to replace their existing devices to keep up with innovation.

Apple has a strong brand name and a large physical store presence in the United States. The widespread popularity of Apple products in the United States has enabled the company to be the only major player in the industry.

Most stores are small and serve their local markets. Strong external competition from big-box retailers has prevented most retailers from expanding their business to more locations to capture a larger market share.

Computer stores aren't heavily regulated. Retailers must comply with labor regulations and accessibility requirements to avoid fines. Retailers aren't directly subject to any tariffs or government regulations that provide them any assistance. However, retailers get some support from the National Retail Federation.

Purchase costs rise amid elevated input prices. The price of semiconductors and electronic components has risen in recent years, making computers more expensive and pushing retailers to pay higher prices.
Computer stores rely heavily on employees for daily operations. However, the adoption of automated solutions has slightly lowered retailers' reliance on human labor.

The geographical spread of computer stores closely reflects the population distribution. Highly populated regions have a larger pool of potential customers, attracting retailers. The Southeast holds the largest share of the population. Florida accounts for the most significant share of retailers because of its large population and favorable regulatory environment.

Laptop and desktop computer sales generate the most revenue. Most consumers have favored laptops for their portability and convenience, especially as the technology has evolved to suit the needs of most users.
Households with incomes of more than $150,000 buy the most computers. Consumers with higher incomes have more resources to allocate toward buying new technologies.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers primarily cater to individual consumers rather than businesses, which require enterprise-wide solutions often outside the capacity of computer stores.
Retailers primarily cater to individual consumers rather than businesses, which require enterprise-wide solutions often outside the capacity of computer stores.
Retailers primarily cater to individual consumers rather than businesses, which require enterprise-wide solutions often outside the capacity of computer stores.
Households making more than $100,000 a year often have more financial freedom than lower-income consumers.
Households making more than $100,000 a year often have more financial freedom than lower-income consumers.
The segment includes retailers, restaurants, wholesalers, manufacturers and other businesses.

products_and_services.product_description: Products in this segment include desktop and laptop computers, peripheral equipment such as printers, scanners, keyboards, computer hardware and other accessories.
Computer software products enable users to customize their computers with various functions and services.
Other electronics include the sales of products such as TVs, DVD players, camcorders, cameras, e-book readers and tablets.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: E-commerce sales measure the total value of online retail sales in the United States.
Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services.
Rising disposable income represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of computers and peripheral equipment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Changes in the price of computers and peripheral equipment directly impact revenue growth.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Private investment in computers and software
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Private investment in computers and software represents the total annual expenditure by businesses on all information processing equipment and software.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Percentage of households with at least one computer
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The percentage of households with at least one computer is estimated using US Census Bureau's Current Population Survey data.

business_locations.location_description: The large population in the Southeast attracts retailers.
Retailers in the West are Concentrated in California.
The Mid-Atlantic and its Metropolitan Cities are Popular Among Retailers.
Retailers in the Southwest also benefit from the region's lower taxes and fewer regulations.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Antitrust laws impact US computer stores by preventing behaviors that restrict competition.
Retailers are subject to labor regulations.
The Americans with Disabilities Act prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Retailers must follow labor laws and accessibility requirements.
The initial cost of securing a visible location, purchasing inventory, hiring staff and advertising can be substantial.
New retailers will struggle to stand out in the heavily saturated industry.

basis_points.basis_description: Computer stores contend with high internal competition.
External competition poses a significant threat.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The nature of the industry keeps market share concentration low
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is comprised of many small retailers that serve their local markets.

concentration_points.concentration_title: New entrants are finding it difficult to compete
concentration_points.concentration_description: New retailers looking to enter the industry will struggle to compete with large, well-established sellers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Input Price Volatility at the Manufacturing Level Pushes Purchase Costs Higher
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Retailers purchase products for resale including computers, peripheral equipment and software.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Because computers are largely discretionary in nature, variations in macroeconomic factors like disposable income and consumer confidence influence computer stores' revenue.

volatility_points.volatility_title: SIGNIFICANT COMPETITION POSES DIFFICULTIES FOR COMPUTER STORES
volatility_points.volatility_description: Large online platforms have contributed to the price-based competition impacting the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Retailers have increasingly adopted new technologies, including point-of-sale and inventory management systems.
Retailers can manage inventory more efficiently by integrating a point-of-sale system.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Many computers are discretionary and customers will often put off purchasing these goods when per capita disposable income is low.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep track of stock levels to ensure that goods are readily available?
FAQs.answer: Retailers use various inventory systems and actively monitor inventory.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Computer stores also provide sales and other commission incentives for employees.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities to expand your reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Large industry companies have increased acquisition activity to include more specialized stores in their portfolio.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to online sales growth over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Retailers have upped online advertisements and presence to meet the growing demand for online shopping.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to keep the most popular products in stock?
FAQs.answer: Using POS and other inventory tracking systems enables retailers to proactively forecast demand.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Associations like the Consumer Technology Association advocate and host events for its members.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly affected profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Companies have anticipated tightened vehicle emissions standards and other energy-related mandates.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for cashflow seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Increasing advertising and running additional promotions and specials throughout the rest of the year can help drive foot traffic.

FAQs.question: Does your company help consumers finance their purchases?
FAQs.answer: Offering to finance can provide customers with a way to make the larger purchases they want to make.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain skilled staff?
FAQs.answer: Computer store staff should be trained in product knowledge and quality customer service.

FAQs.question: Do you cater to a broad range of consumers? How do you decide which products to stock?
FAQs.answer: Retailers must ensure they stock a variety of computer peripherals and software to meet the needs and preferences of a broad range of consumers.

FAQs.question: Is competition with other computer stores high in your immediate area? How competitive are your prices compared with other stores?
FAQs.answer: Computer stores should ensure that they remain competitive at all times with regard to price and product range on offer.

FAQs.question: How does your company adapt during periods of low disposable income levels?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income rises, consumers generally have more income available to purchase industry goods.

FAQs.question: How can you price your computers and peripheral equipment to compete with online retailers?
FAQs.answer: Typically, price changes in computers and peripheral equipment are passed on to the consumer.

FAQs.question: How will increases in private investments in e-commerce sales effect your business?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the value of e-commerce sales directly drives revenue away from computer stores.
